title: My Website
text:
I work full-time at KU Leuven University in Belgium as a PhD researcher. My current position mostly includes research activities, but also involves some teaching and supervising. I’m always open to new projects and collaborations. If you would like to exchange some ideas, please send me a message at olena.holubowska@kuleuven.be



For the past two years, I’ve been assisting with a course on Introduction to Geoprocessing. In this course, students learn how to use Python for geographical analysis



I have a Master’s degree in Mathematical Modelling and Computation from the Technical University of Denmark. Before that, I obtained a Bachelor’s degree in Mechanical Engineering from VIA University College and Beijing Institute of Technology, during which I gained my first experiences as a lecturer (09.2016-02.2017). My initial research experiences were acquired while working at CERN (06.2018 - 06.2019) and Oxford University (07.2019 – 09.2019). My professional background mainly stems from my role as a data analyst at Maersk (12.2019 – 01.05.2021). Recently, I also completed a Postgraduate Certificate: International Module in Spatial Development Planning.



I’m fluent in Polish, English, Python, and R. I have some experience with French and Matlab.

title: Olena Holubowska
text:
They say home is where the heart is, but what if your heart beats in a city not your own?
I’m Olena, a weaver of cityscapes, untangling the threads that bind newcomers and locals. At KU Leuven, I research urban segregation, the whispers of “us” and “them.”
My current expedition? unveiling the hidden narratives etched within mobile phone data, revealing how residents with migrant backgrounds navigate the city’s unseen pathways. Understanding these journeys is the key to crafting cities that hum with belonging, for everyone.

This paper explores urban segregation and how it affects interactions among different groups in cities. Traditionally, segregation has been studied mainly based on where people live, but this study looks at where people spend their time during daily activities as well. Using data from a mobile app for around 620,000 people, the study analyzes differences in the proportion of foreign-born residents in both residential areas and activity spaces. It finds that people tend to visit areas with different proportions of foreign-born residents compared to where they live, but this effect is influenced by individual choices. The study also investigates how this relationship varies across different sizes of cities, finding that mobility may have a greater impact on reducing segregation in larger cities.
